mn101:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati devadahaṃ nāma sakyānaṃ nigamo.
mn101:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near the Sakyan town named Devadaha.
mn101:1.2.comm: Devadaha also appears in SN 22.2 and SN 35.134. The name is explained in the commentary as “royal lake”, taking deva- as a term for kings, and -daha as equivalent to the Sanskrit hrada, “lake”. However it is spelled devadṛśa in the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya (San Mu Kd 17:16). Dṛśa means “sight, appearance”, thus occupying a completely different semantic space than “lake”. It is a Vedic term that commonly describes Agni’s fiery gleam (Rig Veda 3.17.4, 6.10.4, 7.1.1, etc.). This suggests a Pali derivation from √ḍah, “to burn”. This in turn recalls Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.4.1.14, which allegorically depicts the spread of Aryan culture eastward as Agni “burning” (dadāha) the lands, i.e. introducing the civilized practice of Vedic fire worship. I think the meaning of devadaha is, therefore, “burned by the god”, or “place of the god’s flame”. It became famous in later Buddhism as the birthplace of the sisters Māyā and Mahāpajāpatī of the Koliyan clan, the Buddha’s birth mother and foster mother. These details are not mentioned in early texts, however, where the town is said to be Sakyan rather than Koliyan. It is identified with Devdaha in the Rupandehi District of Nepal.

mn101:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn101:2.4.eng: “Mendicants, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn101:2.5.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetu.
mn101:2.5.eng: ‘Everything this individual person experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.
mn101:2.5.comm: The view that all experiences are caused by past kamma is consistently rejected in the suttas (eg. AN 3.61:2.1, SN 36.21). This is reflected in the later Theravada commentaries, which describe five interacting niyāmas, or systems of natural law: seasons (utu), genetics (bīja), moral or immoral deeds (kamma), mind (citta), and principles of the teaching (dhamma). Nonetheless, the view that all experiences are caused by kamma is extremely common among modern Buddhists, and is often heard even from learned scholars. This is a harmful misunderstanding, as it has led to discrimination against the poor and disabled in Buddhist countries. One point of confusion is that rebirth into a particular life is caused by kamma, so in that general sense, kamma is a necessary condition for having a life in which one can experience anything. But the feelings experienced in that life are caused by a variety of things, not necessarily by kamma. | Note the use of purisapuggala (“individual person”) as a Jain idiom. See MN 35:10.7 and note, and SN 22.22 and notes.

mn101:2.6.pli: Iti purāṇānaṃ kammānaṃ tapasā byantībhāvā, navānaṃ kammānaṃ akaraṇā, āyatiṃ anavassavo;
mn101:2.6.eng: So, due to eliminating past deeds by fervent mortification, and not doing any new deeds, there’s nothing to come up in the future.
mn101:2.6.comm: Jains believed that karma was material, made up of particles. The practice of tapas (“fervent mortification”) creates an intense bodily heat which burns off these karmic particles, freeing the soul (jīva) to shine in its intrinsic purity. | This passage also at MN 14:17.7.

mn101:2.7.pli: āyatiṃ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn101:2.7.eng: With no future consequence, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.’
mn101:2.7.comm: The mention of “feeling” after “suffering” here is found consistently in Pali sources, but not in their parallels. | Nijiṇṇa (“worn away”) is a characteristic Jain term that is sometimes applied to kamma in the suttas as well.

mn101:2.8.eng: Such is the doctrine of the Jain ascetics.
mn101:2.8.comm: The idea that the elimination of karma leads to freedom from suffering is indeed a fundamental tenet of Jain thought.

mn101:3.1.pli: Evaṃvādāhaṃ, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhe upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadāmi:
mn101:3.1.eng: I’ve gone up to the Jain ascetics who say this and said,

mn101:3.2.pli: ‘saccaṃ kira tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino—
mn101:3.2.eng: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’

mn101:3.3.pli: yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetu.

mn101:3.4.pli: Iti purāṇānaṃ kammānaṃ tapasā byantībhāvā, navānaṃ kammānaṃ akaraṇā, āyatiṃ anavassavo;

mn101:3.5.pli: āyatiṃ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti?

mn101:3.6.pli: Te ca me, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā evaṃ puṭṭhā ‘āmā’ti paṭijānanti.

mn101:4.3.eng: for sure that you existed in the past, and it is not the case that you did not exist?’

mn101:4.6.pli: akaramheva mayaṃ pubbe pāpakammaṃ, na nākaramhā’ti?
mn101:4.6.eng: for sure that you did bad deeds in the past?’

mn101:4.9.pli: evarūpaṃ vā evarūpaṃ vā pāpakammaṃ akaramhā’ti?
mn101:4.9.eng: that you did such and such bad deeds?’

mn101:4.12.pli: ettakaṃ vā dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ, ettakaṃ vā dukkhaṃ nijjīretabbaṃ, ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatī’ti?
mn101:4.12.eng: that so much suffering has already been worn away? Or that so much suffering still remains to be worn away? Or that when so much suffering is worn away all suffering will have been worn away?’

mn101:4.15.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānaṃ, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadan’ti?
mn101:4.15.eng: about giving up unskillful qualities in this very life and embracing skillful qualities?’

mn101:5.1.pli: ‘Iti kira tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, na jānātha—
mn101:5.1.eng: ‘So it seems that you don’t know any of these things.

mn101:5.2.pli: ahuvamheva mayaṃ pubbe, na nāhuvamhāti, na jānātha—

mn101:5.3.pli: akaramheva mayaṃ pubbe pāpakammaṃ, na nākaramhāti, na jānātha—

mn101:5.4.pli: evarūpaṃ vā evarūpaṃ vā pāpakammaṃ akaramhāti, na jānātha—

mn101:5.5.pli: ettakaṃ vā dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ, ettakaṃ vā dukkhaṃ nijjīretabbaṃ, ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatīti, na jānātha—

mn101:5.6.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānaṃ, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadaṃ;

mn101:5.7.pli: evaṃ sante āyasmantānaṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ na kallamassa veyyākaraṇāya:
mn101:5.7.eng: In that case, it’s not appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.

mn101:5.8.pli: “yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetu.

mn101:5.9.pli: Iti purāṇānaṃ kammānaṃ tapasā byantībhāvā, navānaṃ kammānaṃ akaraṇā, āyatiṃ anavassavo;

mn101:5.10.pli: āyatiṃ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatī”ti.

mn101:6.1.pli: Sace pana tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, jāneyyātha—
mn101:6.1.eng: Now, supposing you did know these things.

mn101:6.2.pli: ahuvamheva mayaṃ pubbe, na nāhuvamhāti, jāneyyātha—

mn101:6.3.pli: akaramheva mayaṃ pubbe pāpakammaṃ, na nākaramhāti, jāneyyātha—

mn101:6.4.pli: evarūpaṃ vā evarūpaṃ vā pāpakammaṃ akaramhāti, jāneyyātha—

mn101:6.5.pli: ettakaṃ vā dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ, ettakaṃ vā dukkhaṃ nijjīretabbaṃ, ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatīti, jāneyyātha—

mn101:6.6.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānaṃ, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadaṃ;

mn101:6.7.pli: evaṃ sante āyasmantānaṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ kallamassa veyyākaraṇāya:
mn101:6.7.eng: In that case, it would be appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.

mn101:6.8.pli: “yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetu.

mn101:6.9.pli: Iti purāṇānaṃ kammānaṃ tapasā byantībhāvā, navānaṃ kammānaṃ akaraṇā, āyatiṃ anavassavo;

mn101:6.10.pli: āyatiṃ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatī”ti.

mn101:7.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, puriso sallena viddho assa savisena gāḷhūpalepanena;
mn101:7.1.eng: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison,

mn101:7.2.pli: so sallassapi vedhanahetu dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyeyya.
mn101:7.2.eng: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.

mn101:7.3.pli: Tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṃ sallakattaṃ upaṭṭhāpeyyuṃ.
mn101:7.3.eng: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.

mn101:7.4.pli: Tassa so bhisakko sallakatto satthena vaṇamukhaṃ parikanteyya;
mn101:7.4.eng: The surgeon would cut open the wound with a scalpel,

mn101:7.5.pli: so satthenapi vaṇamukhassa parikantanahetu dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyeyya.
mn101:7.5.eng: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.

mn101:7.6.pli: Tassa so bhisakko sallakatto esaniyā sallaṃ eseyya;

mn101:7.7.pli: so esaniyāpi sallassa esanāhetu dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyeyya.
mn101:7.7.eng: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.

mn101:7.8.pli: Tassa so bhisakko sallakatto sallaṃ abbuheyya;

mn101:7.9.pli: so sallassapi abbuhanahetu dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyeyya.
mn101:7.9.eng: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.

mn101:7.10.pli: Tassa so bhisakko sallakatto agadaṅgāraṃ vaṇamukhe odaheyya;
mn101:7.10.eng: They’d apply cauterizing medicine to the wound,

mn101:7.11.pli: so agadaṅgārassapi vaṇamukhe odahanahetu dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyeyya.
mn101:7.11.eng: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.

mn101:7.12.pli: So aparena samayena rūḷhena vaṇena sañchavinā arogo assa sukhī serī sayaṃvasī yena kāmaṅgamo.
mn101:7.12.eng: After some time that wound would be healed and the skin regrown. They’d be healthy, happy, autonomous, master of themselves, able to go where they wanted.

mn101:7.14.pli: “ahaṃ kho pubbe sallena viddho ahosiṃ savisena gāḷhūpalepanena.
mn101:7.14.eng: “Earlier I was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison,

mn101:7.15.pli: Sohaṃ sallassapi vedhanahetu dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyiṃ.
mn101:7.15.eng: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.

mn101:7.16.pli: Tassa me mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṃ sallakattaṃ upaṭṭhapesuṃ.
mn101:7.16.eng: My friends and colleagues, relatives and kin got a surgeon to treat me.

mn101:7.17.pli: Tassa me so bhisakko sallakatto satthena vaṇamukhaṃ parikanti;
mn101:7.17.eng: At each step, the treatment was painful.

mn101:7.18.pli: sohaṃ satthenapi vaṇamukhassa parikantanahetu dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyiṃ.

mn101:7.19.pli: Tassa me so bhisakko sallakatto esaniyā sallaṃ esi;

mn101:7.20.pli: so ahaṃ esaniyāpi sallassa esanāhetu dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyiṃ.

mn101:7.21.pli: Tassa me so bhisakko sallakatto sallaṃ abbuhi;

mn101:7.22.pli: sohaṃ sallassapi abbuhanahetu dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyiṃ.

mn101:7.23.pli: Tassa me so bhisakko sallakatto agadaṅgāraṃ vaṇamukhe odahi;

mn101:7.24.pli: sohaṃ agadaṅgārassapi vaṇamukhe odahanahetu dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyiṃ.

mn101:7.25.pli: Somhi etarahi rūḷhena vaṇena sañchavinā arogo sukhī serī sayaṃvasī yena kāmaṅgamo”ti.
mn101:7.25.eng: But these days that wound is healed and the skin regrown. I’m healthy, happy, autonomous, my own master, able to go where I want.”

mn101:8.1.pli: Evameva kho, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, sace tumhe jāneyyātha—
mn101:8.1.eng: In the same way, reverends, if you knew about these things,

mn101:8.2.pli: ahuvamheva mayaṃ pubbe, na nāhuvamhāti, jāneyyātha—

mn101:8.3.pli: akaramheva mayaṃ pubbe pāpakammaṃ, na nākaramhāti, jāneyyātha—

mn101:8.4.pli: evarūpaṃ vā evarūpaṃ vā pāpakammaṃ akaramhāti, jāneyyātha—

mn101:8.5.pli: ettakaṃ vā dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ, ettakaṃ vā dukkhaṃ nijjīretabbaṃ, ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatīti, jāneyyātha—

mn101:8.6.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānaṃ, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadaṃ;

mn101:8.7.pli: evaṃ sante āyasmantānaṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ kallamassa veyyākaraṇāya:
mn101:8.7.eng: it would be appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.

mn101:8.8.pli: “yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetu.

mn101:8.9.pli: Iti purāṇānaṃ kammānaṃ tapasā byantībhāvā, navānaṃ kammānaṃ akaraṇā, āyatiṃ anavassavo;

mn101:8.10.pli: āyatiṃ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatī”ti.

mn101:9.1.pli: Yasmā ca kho tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, na jānātha—
mn101:9.1.eng: But since you don’t know any of these things,

mn101:9.2.pli: ahuvamheva mayaṃ pubbe, na nāhuvamhāti, na jānātha—

mn101:9.3.pli: akaramheva mayaṃ pubbe pāpakammaṃ, na nākaramhāti, na jānātha—

mn101:9.4.pli: evarūpaṃ vā evarūpaṃ vā pāpakammaṃ akaramhāti, na jānātha—

mn101:9.5.pli: ettakaṃ vā dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ, ettakaṃ vā dukkhaṃ nijjīretabbaṃ, ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatīti, na jānātha—

mn101:9.6.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānaṃ, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadaṃ;

mn101:9.7.pli: tasmā āyasmantānaṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ na kallamassa veyyākaraṇāya:
mn101:9.7.eng: it’s not appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.’

mn101:9.8.pli: “yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetu.

mn101:9.9.pli: Iti purāṇānaṃ kammānaṃ tapasā byantībhāvā, navānaṃ kammānaṃ akaraṇā, āyatiṃ anavassavo;

mn101:9.10.pli: āyatiṃ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatī”’ti.

mn101:10.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, te nigaṇṭhā maṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn101:10.1.eng: When I said this, those Jain ascetics said to me,

mn101:10.2.pli: ‘nigaṇṭho, āvuso, nāṭaputto sabbaññū sabbadassāvī, aparisesaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paṭijānāti.
mn101:10.2.eng: ‘Reverend, the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:

mn101:10.3.pli: “Carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṃ samitaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paccupaṭṭhitan”ti.
mn101:10.3.eng: “Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.”

mn101:10.5.pli: “atthi kho vo, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, pubbeva pāpakammaṃ kataṃ, taṃ imāya kaṭukāya dukkarakārikāya nijjīretha,
mn101:10.5.eng: “O reverend Jain ascetics, you have done bad deeds in a past life. Wear them away with these severe and grueling austerities.

mn101:10.6.pli: yaṃ panettha etarahi kāyena saṃvutā vācāya saṃvutā manasā saṃvutā taṃ āyatiṃ pāpakammassa akaraṇaṃ.
mn101:10.6.eng: And when in the present you are restrained in body, speech, and mind, you’re not doing any bad deeds for the future.

mn101:10.7.pli: Iti purāṇānaṃ kammānaṃ tapasā byantībhāvā, navānaṃ kammānaṃ akaraṇā, āyatiṃ anavassavo;
mn101:10.7.eng: So, due to eliminating past deeds by fervent mortification, and not doing any new deeds, there’s nothing to come up in the future.

mn101:10.8.pli: āyatiṃ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatī”ti.
mn101:10.8.eng: With no future consequence, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.”

mn101:10.9.pli: Tañca panamhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca, tena camhā attamanā’ti.
mn101:10.9.eng: We endorse and accept this, and we are satisfied with it.’

mn101:11.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhikkhave, te nigaṇṭhe etadavocaṃ:
mn101:11.1.eng: When they said this, I said to them,

mn101:11.2.pli: ‘pañca kho ime, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, dhammā diṭṭheva dhamme dvidhāvipākā.
mn101:11.2.eng: ‘These five things can be seen to turn out in two different ways.

mn101:11.4.eng: Faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, and acceptance of a view after deliberation.

mn101:11.5.pli: ime kho, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, pañca dhammā diṭṭheva dhamme dvidhāvipākā.
mn101:11.5.eng: These are the five things that can be seen to turn out in two different ways.

mn101:11.6.pli: Tatrāyasmantānaṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ kā atītaṃse satthari saddhā, kā ruci, ko anussavo, ko ākāraparivitakko, kā diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantī’ti.
mn101:11.6.eng: In this case, what faith in your teacher do you have when it comes to the past? What endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, or acceptance of a view after deliberation?’

mn101:11.7.pli: Evaṃvādī kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhesu na kañci sahadhammikaṃ vādapaṭihāraṃ samanupassāmi.
mn101:11.7.eng: When I said this, I did not see any legitimate defense of their doctrine from the Jains.

mn101:12.1.pli: Puna caparāhaṃ, bhikkhave, te nigaṇṭhe evaṃ vadāmi:
mn101:12.1.eng: Furthermore, I said to those Jain ascetics,

mn101:12.3.pli: Yasmiṃ vo samaye tibbo upakkamo hoti tibbaṃ padhānaṃ, tibbā tasmiṃ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha;
mn101:12.3.eng: At a time of intense exertion and striving do you suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion?

mn101:12.4.pli: yasmiṃ pana vo samaye na tibbo upakkamo hoti na tibbaṃ padhānaṃ, na tibbā tasmiṃ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyethā’ti?
mn101:12.4.eng: Whereas at a time without intense exertion and striving do you not suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion?’

mn101:12.5.pli: ‘Yasmiṃ no, āvuso gotama, samaye tibbo upakkamo hoti tibbaṃ padhānaṃ, tibbā tasmiṃ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyāma;
mn101:12.5.eng: ‘Reverend Gotama, at a time of intense exertion we suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion,

mn101:12.6.pli: yasmiṃ pana no samaye na tibbo upakkamo hoti na tibbaṃ padhānaṃ, na tibbā tasmiṃ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyāmā’ti.

mn101:13.1.pli: ‘Iti kira, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, yasmiṃ vo samaye tibbo upakkamo hoti tibbaṃ padhānaṃ, tibbā tasmiṃ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha;
mn101:13.1.eng: ‘So it seems that only at a time of intense exertion do you suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion,

mn101:13.2.pli: yasmiṃ pana vo samaye na tibbo upakkamo hoti na tibbaṃ padhānaṃ, na tibbā tasmiṃ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha.

mn101:13.3.pli: Evaṃ sante āyasmantānaṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ na kallamassa veyyākaraṇāya:
mn101:13.3.eng: In that case, it’s not appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare:

mn101:13.4.pli: “yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetu.
mn101:13.4.eng: “Everything this individual person experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds. …”

mn101:13.5.pli: Iti purāṇānaṃ kammānaṃ tapasā byantībhāvā, navānaṃ kammānaṃ akaraṇā, āyatiṃ anavassavo;

mn101:13.6.pli: āyatiṃ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatī”ti.

mn101:14.1.pli: Sace, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, yasmiṃ vo samaye tibbo upakkamo hoti tibbaṃ padhānaṃ, na tibbā tasmiṃ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha;
mn101:14.1.eng: If at a time of intense exertion you did not suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion,

mn101:14.2.pli: yasmiṃ pana vo samaye na tibbo upakkamo hoti na tibbaṃ padhānaṃ, tibbā tasmiṃ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha;
mn101:14.2.eng: and if without intense exertion you did experience such feelings,

mn101:14.3.pli: evaṃ sante āyasmantānaṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ kallamassa veyyākaraṇāya:
mn101:14.3.eng: it would be appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.

mn101:14.4.pli: “yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetu.

mn101:14.5.pli: Iti purāṇānaṃ kammānaṃ tapasā byantībhāvā, navānaṃ kammānaṃ akaraṇā, āyatiṃ anavassavo;

mn101:14.6.pli: āyatiṃ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatī”ti.

mn101:15.1.pli: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, yasmiṃ vo samaye tibbo upakkamo hoti tibbaṃ padhānaṃ, tibbā tasmiṃ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha;
mn101:15.1.eng: But since this is not the case,

mn101:15.2.pli: yasmiṃ pana vo samaye na tibbo upakkamo hoti na tibbaṃ padhānaṃ, na tibbā tasmiṃ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha;

mn101:15.3.pli: te tumhe sāmaṃyeva opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānā avijjā aññāṇā sammohā vipaccetha:
mn101:15.3.eng: aren’t you experiencing painful, sharp feelings due only to your own exertion, which out of ignorance, unknowing, and confusion you misconstrue to imply:
mn101:15.3.comm: This is a difficult sentence, and different translators handle it in quite different ways. I take vipaccetha as second plural optative, intended as a rhetorical question. The sense, I think, plays on the common meaning of “ripen”, but in the sense “make something out of it that it isn’t”, i.e. (mis)construe.

mn101:15.4.pli: “yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetu.
mn101:15.4.eng: “Everything this individual person experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds. …”?’

mn101:15.5.pli: Iti purāṇānaṃ kammānaṃ tapasā byantībhāvā, navānaṃ kammānaṃ akaraṇā, āyatiṃ anavassavo;

mn101:15.6.pli: āyatiṃ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nijjiṇṇaṃ bhavissatī”’ti.

mn101:15.7.pli: Evaṃvādīpi kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhesu na kañci sahadhammikaṃ vādapaṭihāraṃ samanupassāmi.
mn101:15.7.eng: When I said this, I did not see any legitimate defense of their doctrine from the Jains.

mn101:16.1.pli: Puna caparāhaṃ, bhikkhave, te nigaṇṭhe evaṃ vadāmi:
mn101:16.1.eng: Furthermore, I said to those Jain ascetics,

mn101:16.2.pli: ‘taṃ kiṃ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṃ kammaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā samparāyavedanīyaṃ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
mn101:16.2.eng: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced in this life, can exertion make it be experienced in lives to come?’
mn101:16.2.comm: Just as different deeds have differing characteristics, the results of those deeds also have different characteristics, which constrain the result in certain ways. This does not mean that they are fully deterministic, however. Compare the sprouting of a seed. A mango seed cannot give rise to an orange tree. And it has certain conditions under which it cannot sprout—if it is out of season, or the soil is inadequate, or there is no water, etc. Still, there are many different ways that it can sprout, and the tree and its fruit that result will vary according to conditions.

mn101:16.4.pli: ‘Yaṃ panidaṃ kammaṃ samparāyavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
mn101:16.4.eng: ‘But if a deed is to be experienced in lives to come, can exertion make it be experienced in this life?’

mn101:17.1.pli: ‘Taṃ kiṃ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṃ kammaṃ sukhavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā dukkhavedanīyaṃ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
mn101:17.1.eng: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced as pleasure, can exertion make it be experienced as pain?’

mn101:17.3.pli: ‘Yaṃ panidaṃ kammaṃ dukkhavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā sukhavedanīyaṃ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
mn101:17.3.eng: ‘But if a deed is to be experienced as pain, can exertion make it be experienced as pleasure?’

mn101:18.1.pli: ‘Taṃ kiṃ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṃ kammaṃ paripakkavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā aparipakkavedanīyaṃ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
mn101:18.1.eng: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced when fully ripened, can exertion make it be experienced when not fully ripened?’

mn101:18.3.pli: ‘Yaṃ panidaṃ kammaṃ aparipakkavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā paripakkavedanīyaṃ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
mn101:18.3.eng: ‘But if a deed is to be experienced when not fully ripened, can exertion make it be experienced when fully ripened?’

mn101:19.1.pli: ‘Taṃ kiṃ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṃ kammaṃ bahuvedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā appavedanīyaṃ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
mn101:19.1.eng: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced strongly, can exertion make it be experienced weakly?’

mn101:19.3.pli: ‘Yaṃ panidaṃ kammaṃ appavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā bahuvedanīyaṃ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
mn101:19.3.eng: ‘But if a deed is to be experienced weakly, can exertion make it be experienced strongly?’

mn101:20.1.pli: ‘Taṃ kiṃ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṃ kammaṃ savedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā avedanīyaṃ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
mn101:20.1.eng: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced, can exertion make it not be experienced?’

mn101:20.3.pli: ‘Yaṃ panidaṃ kammaṃ avedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā savedanīyaṃ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
mn101:20.3.eng: ‘But if a deed is not to be experienced, can exertion make it be experienced?’
mn101:20.3.comm: This is a deed that has no opportunity to bear fruit, like a good seed on barren soil.

mn101:21.1.pli: ‘Iti kira, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṃ kammaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā samparāyavedanīyaṃ hotūti alabbhametaṃ, yaṃ panidaṃ kammaṃ samparāyavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ hotūti alabbhametaṃ, yamidaṃ kammaṃ sukhavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā dukkhavedanīyaṃ hotūti alabbhametaṃ, yamidaṃ kammaṃ dukkhavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā sukhavedanīyaṃ hotūti alabbhametaṃ, yamidaṃ kammaṃ paripakkavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā aparipakkavedanīyaṃ hotūti alabbhametaṃ, yamidaṃ kammaṃ aparipakkavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā paripakkavedanīyaṃ hotūti alabbhametaṃ, yamidaṃ kammaṃ bahuvedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā appavedanīyaṃ hotūti alabbhametaṃ, yamidaṃ kammaṃ appavedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā bahuvedanīyaṃ hotūti alabbhametaṃ, yamidaṃ kammaṃ savedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā avedanīyaṃ hotūti alabbhametaṃ, yamidaṃ kammaṃ avedanīyaṃ taṃ upakkamena vā padhānena vā savedanīyaṃ hotūti alabbhametaṃ;
mn101:21.1.eng: ‘So it seems that exertion cannot change the way deeds are experienced in any of these ways.

mn101:21.2.pli: evaṃ sante āyasmantānaṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ aphalo upakkamo hoti, aphalaṃ padhānaṃ’.
mn101:21.2.eng: This being so, your exertion and striving are fruitless.’

mn101:22.1.eng: Such is the doctrine of the Jain ascetics.

mn101:22.2.pli: Evaṃvādīnaṃ, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhānaṃ dasa sahadhammikā vādānuvādā gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchanti.
mn101:22.2.eng: Saying this, the Jain ascetics deserve rebuttal and criticism on ten legitimate grounds.
mn101:22.2.comm: The “ten legitimate grounds” are, as explained below, the five grounds and their inversions. Whether or not the ground is true, the Jains deserve censure.

mn101:22.3.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti;
mn101:22.3.eng: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds,

mn101:22.4.pli: addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā pubbe dukkaṭakammakārino yaṃ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti.
mn101:22.4.eng: clearly the Jains have done bad deeds in the past, since they now experience such intense pain.

mn101:22.5.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā issaranimmānahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti;
mn101:22.5.eng: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of God Almighty’s creation,
mn101:22.5.comm: “God Almighty” is issara, the creator deity. See also AN 3.61.

mn101:22.6.pli: addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā pāpakena issarena nimmitā yaṃ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti.
mn101:22.6.eng: clearly the Jains were created by a bad God, since they now experience such intense pain.

mn101:22.7.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā saṅgatibhāvahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti;
mn101:22.7.eng: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of circumstance and nature,
mn101:22.7.comm: This is the Ājīvika doctrine of the Bamboo-staffed Ascetic Gosāla, for which see DN 2:20.6, MN 60:21.7, and AN 3.61. The mention of Ājīvika doctrines here and in the next section reflect their closeness with the Jains.

mn101:22.8.pli: addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā pāpasaṅgatikā yaṃ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti.
mn101:22.8.eng: clearly the Jains arise from bad circumstances, since they now experience such intense pain.

mn101:22.9.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā abhijātihetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti;
mn101:22.9.eng: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of the class of rebirth,
mn101:22.9.comm: See AN 6.57 for a fuller discussion of this Ājīvika doctrine.

mn101:22.10.pli: addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā pāpābhijātikā yaṃ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti.
mn101:22.10.eng: clearly the Jains have been reborn in a bad class, since they now experience such intense pain.

mn101:22.11.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti;
mn101:22.11.eng: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of exertion in this life,

mn101:22.12.pli: addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā evarūpā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamā yaṃ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti.
mn101:22.12.eng: clearly the Jains exert themselves badly in this life, since they now experience such intense pain.
mn101:22.12.comm: PTS and BJT editions have the expected pāpadiṭṭhadhammūpakkamā.

mn101:22.13.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā;
mn101:22.13.eng: The Jains deserve criticism whether or not sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds,

mn101:22.14.pli: no ce sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā.

mn101:22.15.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā issaranimmānahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā;

mn101:22.16.pli: no ce sattā issaranimmānahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā.

mn101:22.17.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā saṅgatibhāvahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā;

mn101:22.18.pli: no ce sattā saṅgatibhāvahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā.

mn101:22.19.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā abhijātihetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā;

mn101:22.20.pli: no ce sattā abhijātihetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā.

mn101:22.21.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā;

mn101:22.22.pli: no ce sattā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā.

mn101:22.23.eng: Such is the doctrine of the Jain ascetics.

mn101:22.24.pli: Evaṃvādīnaṃ, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhānaṃ ime dasa sahadhammikā vādānuvādā gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchanti.
mn101:22.24.eng: The Jain ascetics who say this deserve rebuttal and criticism on these ten legitimate grounds.

mn101:22.25.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, aphalo upakkamo hoti, aphalaṃ padhānaṃ.
mn101:22.25.eng: That’s how exertion and striving is fruitless.

mn101:23.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṃ padhānaṃ?
mn101:23.1.eng: And how is exertion and striving fruitful?

mn101:23.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na heva anaddhabhūtaṃ attānaṃ dukkhena addhabhāveti, dhammikañca sukhaṃ na pariccajati, tasmiñca sukhe anadhimucchito hoti.
mn101:23.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant does not bring suffering upon themselves; and they don’t forsake legitimate pleasure, but they’re not besotted with that pleasure.
mn101:23.2.comm: Literally, a mendicant “does not oppress the unoppressed self with suffering”. For addhabhūta see SN 35.29.

mn101:23.4.pli: ‘imassa kho me dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṃ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti, imassa pana me dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṃ bhāvayato virāgo hotī’ti.
mn101:23.4.eng: ‘When I actively strive I become dispassionate towards this source of suffering. But when I develop equanimity I become dispassionate towards this other source of suffering.’

mn101:23.5.pli: So yassa hi khvāssa dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṃ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti, saṅkhāraṃ tattha padahati.
mn101:23.5.eng: So they either actively strive or develop equanimity as appropriate.

mn101:23.6.pli: Yassa panassa dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṃ bhāvayato virāgo hoti, upekkhaṃ tattha bhāveti.

mn101:23.7.pli: Tassa tassa dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṃ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti—
mn101:23.7.eng: Through active striving they become dispassionate towards that specific source of suffering,

mn101:23.8.eng: and so that suffering is worn away.

mn101:23.9.pli: Tassa tassa dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṃ bhāvayato virāgo hoti—
mn101:23.9.eng: Through developing equanimity they become dispassionate towards that other source of suffering,

mn101:23.10.eng: and so that suffering is worn away.

mn101:24.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso itthiyā sāratto paṭibaddhacitto tibbacchando tibbāpekkho.
mn101:24.1.eng: Suppose a man is in love with a woman, full of intense desire and lust.

mn101:24.2.pli: So taṃ itthiṃ passeyya aññena purisena saddhiṃ santiṭṭhantiṃ sallapantiṃ sañjagghantiṃ saṃhasantiṃ.
mn101:24.2.eng: Then he sees her standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing.

mn101:24.4.pli: api nu tassa purisassa amuṃ itthiṃ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṃ santiṭṭhantiṃ sallapantiṃ sañjagghantiṃ saṃhasantiṃ uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā”ti?
mn101:24.4.eng: Would that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for him?”

mn101:24.7.pli: “Amu hi, bhante, puriso amussā itthiyā sāratto paṭibaddhacitto tibbacchando tibbāpekkho.
mn101:24.7.eng: Because that man is in love with that woman, full of intense desire and lust.”

mn101:24.8.pli: Tasmā taṃ itthiṃ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṃ santiṭṭhantiṃ sallapantiṃ sañjagghantiṃ saṃhasantiṃ uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā”ti.

mn101:25.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho amussā itthiyā sāratto paṭibaddhacitto tibbacchando tibbāpekkho.
mn101:25.2.eng: ‘I’m in love with that woman, full of intense desire and lust.

mn101:25.3.pli: Tassa me amuṃ itthiṃ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṃ santiṭṭhantiṃ sallapantiṃ sañjagghantiṃ saṃhasantiṃ uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā.
mn101:25.3.eng: When I saw her standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing, it gave rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for me.

mn101:25.4.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yo me amussā itthiyā chandarāgo taṃ pajaheyyan’ti.
mn101:25.4.eng: Why don’t I give up that desire and lust for that woman?’

mn101:25.5.pli: So yo amussā itthiyā chandarāgo taṃ pajaheyya.

mn101:25.6.pli: So taṃ itthiṃ passeyya aparena samayena aññena purisena saddhiṃ santiṭṭhantiṃ sallapantiṃ sañjagghantiṃ saṃhasantiṃ.
mn101:25.6.eng: Some time later he sees her again standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing.

mn101:25.8.pli: api nu tassa purisassa amuṃ itthiṃ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṃ santiṭṭhantiṃ sallapantiṃ sañjagghantiṃ saṃhasantiṃ uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā”ti?
mn101:25.8.eng: Would that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for him?”

mn101:25.11.pli: “Amu hi, bhante, puriso amussā itthiyā virāgo.
mn101:25.11.eng: Because he no longer desires that woman.”

mn101:25.12.pli: Tasmā taṃ itthiṃ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṃ santiṭṭhantiṃ sallapantiṃ sañjagghantiṃ saṃhasantiṃ na uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā”ti.

mn101:26.1.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na heva anaddhabhūtaṃ attānaṃ dukkhena addhabhāveti, dhammikañca sukhaṃ na pariccajati, tasmiñca sukhe anadhimucchito hoti.
mn101:26.1.eng: “In the same way, a mendicant does not bring suffering upon themselves; and they don’t forsake legitimate pleasure, but they’re not besotted with that pleasure.

mn101:26.3.pli: ‘imassa kho me dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṃ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti, imassa pana me dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṃ bhāvayato virāgo hotī’ti.
mn101:26.3.eng: ‘When I actively strive I become dispassionate towards this source of suffering. But when I develop equanimity I become dispassionate towards this other source of suffering.’

mn101:26.4.pli: So yassa hi khvāssa dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṃ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti, saṅkhāraṃ tattha padahati;
mn101:26.4.eng: So they either actively strive or develop equanimity as appropriate.

mn101:26.5.pli: yassa panassa dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṃ bhāvayato virāgo hoti, upekkhaṃ tattha bhāveti.

mn101:26.6.pli: Tassa tassa dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṃ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti—
mn101:26.6.eng: Through active striving they become dispassionate towards that specific source of suffering,

mn101:26.7.eng: and so that suffering is worn away.

mn101:26.8.pli: Tassa tassa dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṃ bhāvayato virāgo hoti—
mn101:26.8.eng: Through developing equanimity they become dispassionate towards that other source of suffering,

mn101:26.9.eng: and so that suffering is worn away.

mn101:26.10.pli: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṃ padhānaṃ.
mn101:26.10.eng: That’s how exertion and striving is fruitful.

mn101:27.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:

mn101:27.2.pli: ‘yathāsukhaṃ kho me viharato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
mn101:27.2.eng: ‘When I live as I please, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.

mn101:27.3.pli: dukkhāya pana me attānaṃ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn101:27.3.eng: But when I strive painfully, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.

mn101:27.6.pli: Tassa dukkhāya attānaṃ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn101:27.6.eng: and as they do so unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.

mn101:27.7.pli: So na aparena samayena dukkhāya attānaṃ padahati.
mn101:27.7.eng: After some time, they no longer strive painfully.

mn101:27.9.pli: Yassa hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu atthāya dukkhāya attānaṃ padaheyya svāssa attho abhinipphanno hoti.
mn101:27.9.eng: Because they have accomplished the goal for which they strived painfully.

mn101:27.10.pli: Tasmā na aparena samayena dukkhāya attānaṃ padahati.

mn101:28.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, usukāro tejanaṃ dvīsu alātesu ātāpeti paritāpeti ujuṃ karoti kammaniyaṃ.
mn101:28.1.eng: Suppose an arrowsmith was heating an arrow shaft between two firebrands, making it straight and fit for use.

mn101:29.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, usukārassa tejanaṃ dvīsu alātesu ātāpitaṃ hoti paritāpitaṃ ujuṃ kataṃ kammaniyaṃ, na so taṃ aparena samayena usukāro tejanaṃ dvīsu alātesu ātāpeti paritāpeti ujuṃ karoti kammaniyaṃ.
mn101:29.1.eng: After it’s been made straight and fit for use, they’d no longer heat it to make it straight and fit for use.

mn101:29.3.pli: Yassa hi so, bhikkhave, atthāya usukāro tejanaṃ dvīsu alātesu ātāpeyya paritāpeyya ujuṃ kareyya kammaniyaṃ svāssa attho abhinipphanno hoti.
mn101:29.3.eng: Because they have accomplished the goal for which they heated it.

mn101:29.4.pli: Tasmā na aparena samayena usukāro tejanaṃ dvīsu alātesu ātāpeti paritāpeti ujuṃ karoti kammaniyaṃ.

mn101:29.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:
mn101:29.5.eng: In the same way, a mendicant reflects:

mn101:29.6.pli: ‘yathāsukhaṃ kho me viharato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
mn101:29.6.eng: ‘When I live as I please, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.

mn101:29.7.pli: dukkhāya pana me attānaṃ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn101:29.7.eng: But when I strive painfully, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.

mn101:29.10.pli: Tassa dukkhāya attānaṃ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.

mn101:29.11.pli: So na aparena samayena dukkhāya attānaṃ padahati.

mn101:29.13.pli: Yassa hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu atthāya dukkhāya attānaṃ padaheyya svāssa attho abhinipphanno hoti.

mn101:29.14.pli: Tasmā na aparena samayena dukkhāya attānaṃ padahati.
mn101:29.14.eng: After some time, they no longer strive painfully.

mn101:29.15.pli: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṃ padhānaṃ.
mn101:29.15.eng: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

mn101:30.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idha tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā.
mn101:30.1.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.

mn101:30.2.pli: So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
mn101:30.2.eng: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

mn101:30.3.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
mn101:30.3.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

mn101:31.1.pli: Taṃ dhammaṃ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṃ vā kule paccājāto.
mn101:31.1.eng: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.

mn101:31.2.pli: So taṃ dhammaṃ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṃ paṭilabhati.
mn101:31.2.eng: They gain faith in the Realized One,

mn101:31.3.pli: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:

mn101:31.4.eng: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.

mn101:31.5.pli: Nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ.
mn101:31.5.eng: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.

mn101:31.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
mn101:31.6.eng: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

mn101:31.7.pli: So aparena samayena appaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya, appaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
mn101:31.7.eng: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn101:32.1.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno bhikkhūnaṃ sikkhāsājīvasamāpanno pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho, lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
mn101:32.1.eng: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.

mn101:32.2.pli: Adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.
mn101:32.2.eng: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.

mn101:32.3.pli: Abrahmacariyaṃ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
mn101:32.3.eng: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.

mn101:32.4.pli: Musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṃvādako lokassa.
mn101:32.4.eng: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.

mn101:32.5.pli: Pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṃ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṃ akkhātā amūsaṃ bhedāya—iti bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātā sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
mn101:32.5.eng: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.

mn101:32.6.pli: Pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
mn101:32.6.eng: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.

mn101:32.7.pli: Samphappalāpaṃ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā kālena sāpadesaṃ pariyantavatiṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ.
mn101:32.7.eng: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.

mn101:32.8.eng: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.

mn101:32.9.eng: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.

mn101:32.10.eng: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .

mn101:32.11.eng: They refrain from attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.

mn101:32.12.eng: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.

mn101:32.13.eng: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,

mn101:32.22.eng: They refrain from running errands and messages;

mn101:32.26.eng: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.

mn101:33.1.pli: So santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena, kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
mn101:33.1.eng: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.

mn101:33.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti sapattabhārova ḍeti;
mn101:33.2.eng: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.

mn101:33.3.pli: evameva bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena, kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena; so yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
mn101:33.3.eng: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.

mn101:33.4.pli: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ anavajjasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
mn101:33.4.eng: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.

mn101:34.1.pli: So cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
mn101:34.1.eng: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

mn101:34.2.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
mn101:34.2.eng: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.

mn101:34.3.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

mn101:34.4.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

mn101:34.5.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

mn101:34.6.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

mn101:34.7.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
mn101:34.7.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

mn101:34.8.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṃ, manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
mn101:34.8.eng: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.

mn101:34.9.pli: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ abyāsekasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
mn101:34.9.eng: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.

mn101:35.1.pli: So abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
mn101:35.1.eng: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

mn101:36.1.pli: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato
mn101:36.1.eng: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,

mn101:36.2.pli: vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ.
mn101:36.2.eng: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

mn101:36.3.pli: So pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā, ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya, parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
mn101:36.3.eng: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.

mn101:37.1.pli: So abhijjhaṃ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodheti.
mn101:37.1.eng: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.

mn101:37.2.pli: Byāpādapadosaṃ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādapadosā cittaṃ parisodheti.
mn101:37.2.eng: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.

mn101:37.3.pli: Thinamiddhaṃ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṃ parisodheti.
mn101:37.3.eng: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.

mn101:37.4.pli: Uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṃ parisodheti.
mn101:37.4.eng: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.

mn101:37.5.pli: Vicikicchaṃ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṃ parisodheti.
mn101:37.5.eng: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

mn101:38.1.pli: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
mn101:38.1.eng: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

mn101:38.2.pli: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn101:38.2.eng: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn101:38.3.pli: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṃ padhānaṃ.
mn101:38.3.eng: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

mn101:39.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn101:39.1.eng: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn101:39.2.pli: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṃ padhānaṃ.
mn101:39.2.eng: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

mn101:40.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti. Yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn101:40.1.eng: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

mn101:40.2.pli: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṃ padhānaṃ.
mn101:40.2.eng: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

mn101:41.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn101:41.1.eng: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

mn101:41.2.pli: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṃ padhānaṃ.
mn101:41.2.eng: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

mn101:42.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn101:42.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.

mn101:42.2.pli: So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
mn101:42.2.eng: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

mn101:42.3.pli: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṃ padhānaṃ.
mn101:42.3.eng: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

mn101:43.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn101:43.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.

mn101:43.2.pli: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
mn101:43.2.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understood how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

mn101:43.3.pli: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṃ padhānaṃ.
mn101:43.3.eng: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

mn101:44.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn101:44.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

mn101:44.2.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti;
mn101:44.2.eng: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

mn101:44.3.pli: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn101:44.3.eng: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.

mn101:45.1.pli: Tassa evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati.
mn101:45.1.eng: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

mn101:45.2.eng: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

mn101:45.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
mn101:45.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

mn101:45.4.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṃ padhānaṃ.
mn101:45.4.eng: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.

mn101:46.1.eng: Such is the doctrine of the Realized One.

mn101:46.2.pli: Evaṃvādīnaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgatānaṃ dasa sahadhammikā pāsaṃsaṭṭhānā āgacchanti.
mn101:46.2.eng: Saying this, the Realized One deserves praise on ten legitimate grounds.

mn101:46.3.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti;
mn101:46.3.eng: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds,

mn101:46.4.pli: addhā, bhikkhave, tathāgato pubbe sukatakammakārī yaṃ etarahi evarūpā anāsavā sukhā vedanā vedeti.
mn101:46.4.eng: clearly the Realized One has done good deeds in the past, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.

mn101:46.5.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā issaranimmānahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti;
mn101:46.5.eng: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of God Almighty’s creation,

mn101:46.6.pli: addhā, bhikkhave, tathāgato bhaddakena issarena nimmito yaṃ etarahi evarūpā anāsavā sukhā vedanā vedeti.
mn101:46.6.eng: clearly the Realized One was created by a good God, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.

mn101:46.7.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā saṅgatibhāvahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti;
mn101:46.7.eng: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of circumstance and nature,

mn101:46.8.pli: addhā, bhikkhave, tathāgato kalyāṇasaṅgatiko yaṃ etarahi evarūpā anāsavā sukhā vedanā vedeti.
mn101:46.8.eng: clearly the Realized One arises from good circumstances, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.

mn101:46.9.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā abhijātihetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti;
mn101:46.9.eng: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of the class of rebirth,

mn101:46.10.pli: addhā, bhikkhave, tathāgato kalyāṇābhijātiko yaṃ etarahi evarūpā anāsavā sukhā vedanā vedeti.
mn101:46.10.eng: clearly the Realized One was reborn in a good class, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.

mn101:46.11.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti;
mn101:46.11.eng: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of exertion in this life,

mn101:46.12.pli: addhā, bhikkhave, tathāgato kalyāṇadiṭṭhadhammūpakkamo yaṃ etarahi evarūpā anāsavā sukhā vedanā vedeti.
mn101:46.12.eng: clearly the Realized One exerts himself well in this life, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.

mn101:46.13.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, pāsaṃso tathāgato;
mn101:46.13.eng: The Realized One deserves praise whether or not sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds,

mn101:46.14.pli: no ce sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, pāsaṃso tathāgato.

mn101:46.15.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā issaranimmānahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, pāsaṃso tathāgato;

mn101:46.16.pli: no ce sattā issaranimmānahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, pāsaṃso tathāgato.

mn101:46.17.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā saṅgatibhāvahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, pāsaṃso tathāgato;

mn101:46.18.pli: no ce sattā saṅgatibhāvahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, pāsaṃso tathāgato.

mn101:46.19.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā abhijātihetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, pāsaṃso tathāgato;

mn101:46.20.pli: no ce sattā abhijātihetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, pāsaṃso tathāgato.

mn101:46.21.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, pāsaṃso tathāgato;

mn101:46.22.pli: no ce sattā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamahetu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, pāsaṃso tathāgato.

mn101:46.23.eng: Such is the doctrine of the Realized One.

mn101:46.24.pli: Evaṃvādīnaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgatānaṃ ime dasa sahadhammikā pāsaṃsaṭṭhānā āgacchantī”ti.
mn101:46.24.eng: Saying this, the Realized One deserves praise on these ten legitimate grounds.”

mn101:46.25.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn101:46.26.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn101:46.26.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
